title: Pork & Holy Basil Stir-fry
intro: Also known as Pad Kra Pao, this a popular Thai dish that is actually very simple to cook up.
steps: Prepare the chilli paste by grinding chilli padi and garlic in a mortar and pestle. Adjust the quantities according to your own spice tolerance. Using a food processor or simply mincing it with a knife are possible alternatives
Heat a dash oil in a pan and fry the chilli paste for about a minute or two. Do avoid getting the fumes in your eyes
Add the pork mince and break it up well and allow to brown evenly
Add oyster sauce, fish sauce and soy sauce according to taste and mix well
Once the mince is cooked, turn off the heat add stir basil leaves through the stir-fry
closingRemarks: Best served over rice alongside a fried egg. Pork mince can be replaced with mince or chunks of other protein like chicken or beef. Firm tofu could also work as a meat-free option. Holy basil can be hard to fine, in which case regular basil works fine.

title: Egg Fried Rice
intro: Honestly one of the most versatile meals you can have. Essentially any and i mean ANY ingredient can be added to the base dish, whether it be your choice of protein or any leftover veg you have in the fridge.
steps: Heat some oil in a pan and start cooking your choice of protein or whatever ingredients you wish to add if any. If using scallions/spring onions, the white sections can be added here
Push your ingredients to the side and crack an egg or two into the pan
Allow the egg(s) to set for a few seconds before breaking them up and incorporating them with the rest of your ingredients
Add rice, preferably leftover day old rice, but cooked rice works as well
Add light soy sauce around the edge of the pan and continue to mix till your rice is evenly mixed with the rest of the ingredients. Add any other seasoning here as well
Add the green sections of your scallions/spring onions and mix
closingRemarks: Especially good way to clear leftover rice from previous meals. My personal favourite additions to the base version are tuna, kimchi and an additional egg on top to create a korean-inspired fried rice that also takes less than 15 minutes to prepare and make.

title: Pork and Crab Meatballs
intro: A family favourite I manages to learn from my grandmother; She usually makes a big batch of them leading into Chinese New Year to compliment our many steamboat/hotpot reunion meals.
steps: In a large mixing bowl, add all the listed ingredients and mix well
Knead the mixture and let firm in the fridge for about 30 minutes
Heat up a pot of water or soup/stock
Oil your hands and form the mixture into balls each approximately the size of a ping pong ball
Let the meatballs cook till they float, fish them out and let them cool
closingRemarks: The meatballs can be stored in the fridge or freezer for a few days or weeks respectively. Simply heating them up in some soup is enough. Pairs well with anything to rice, soups and noodles

title: Milk Tea
intro: This is the simpler version of two recipes I've tried and honestly results in milk tea very similar to ones you can get from the stores
steps: In a pot on medium heat, bring the milk to a soft simmer
Add the tea leaves and let steep for 2 minutes
Add the sugar and stir for about a minute until the sugar has dissolved
Turn off the heat and let cool for a bit
Strain the tea and serve either hot or cold
closingRemarks: This can satisfy your milk tea cravings in honestly under 10 minutes. If you do not have loose tea leaves or a sieve/strainer, you could just use teabags. If you wish to elevate it further, you can steep the leaves in minimal water first, before dissolving in the sugar and lastly the milk.

title: Mac & Cheese
intro: This used to be my favourite food back in kindergarten. Looking back, it was definitely less cheesy and more like fried macaroni with cheese slapped on it, but know after trying the 'actual' dish, I still enjoy it quite a bit.
ingredients: Choice of toppings eg. Bread crumbs, Bacon bits
steps: Boil and cook your choice of pasta to al dente. Continue to next steps while waiting
In another pot or deep pan, melt some butter/heat up some oil
Add an equal amount of flour and mix to form a roux. Let the flour cook out but be careful not to burn the roux
Slowly add the milk in, consistently stirring to incorporate it with the roux, eventually making a bechamel sauce
Add in your choice of cheeses and season it well to form your cheese sauce
Mix your cheese sauce into your pasta and transfer to a large baking dish
Add your toppings and finish with another layer of cheese if you like
Bake at 200Â°C until the top is golden brown
closingRemarks: Good sharing meal to accompany other side dishes

title: Corned Beef Silog
intro: This Filipino breakfast classic is really quick to make and pretty filling too.
steps: Start off by frying an egg in oil to your desired doneness. I prefer mine with a runny yolk
Set aside the egg; Saute your diced garlic and onions in the remaining oil till fragrant
Add your corned beef and continue cooking

You can add a small amount of broth and season with salt and pepper here, but I find the corned beef I get sufficiently salty on its own. I also let the beef crisp up on the bottom before moving it around for added texture
Serve with some fried or plain rice with the fried egg on top. Garnish with spring onions if you have it
closingRemarks: Quick hearty breakfast for lazy people like me, especially if you have leftover rice which you can also quickly heat up. Nothing is stopping you from stir frying with some veg on the side or with the beef as well.

title: Shakshuka
intro: A popular North African meal that is surprisingly as healthy as it is delicious
steps: Chop your bell peppers and onion and cook in a large pan with olive oil for till onion becomes translucent (about 5 minutes)
Add garlic and the spices and continue cooking for a bit
Pour in the can of tomatoes/diced fresh tomatoes and break them apart with a large sppon or spatula
Season with salt and pepper and bring the sauce to a simmer
Make a few divots/wells in the sauce and crack your eggs in them. Cover with a lid and let cook to your desired egg doneness
Garnish with chopped cilantro/parsley or both
Eat as is or serve with bread
closingRemarks: Really easy way to pack lots of vegetables into a meal. The base (without eggs) is also easily kept as leftovers or frozen to be reheated later. You could also add your choice of protein like mince for a heartier meal.
